div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; overflow: hidden; max-height: 130px; max-width: 310px; width: 310px; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.p: - Render Â a scatterplot with a smoother, add a slider to change control smoothing.
- Go further and add a selection box that draws a secondary smoother.

div.div:
R function to calculate points of trendline and return converted co-ordinates as a string and update trendline
Â (user could have an option to choose what kind of trendline they wish to generate? + must be asynchronous)

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; width: 116px; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center;
div.div: Record what's been updated (additional slider, trendline functions)

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; width: 116px; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center;

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; width: 318px; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center;

div.div: The R function is too specific for this example.Â
If we happen to want to change the bin-widths of a histogram that are controlled by a slider, that R function must be changed.

We could consider different ways to write up the R function (or get the user to express what they want in R, and we take care of the co-ordinate conversion? maybe?).
drawPlot(x, y, data, type = "scatter")
# possible to separate trendline?
addToPlot(trendline, formula = y ~x, type = "smooth", name = 'trendline')
addSlider(control.on= 'trendline', control.arg = "span",Â min= 0, max = 1, default.value = 0.5)Â
#or split last function into two - where user can define an R function themselves??

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; width: 96px; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center;
div.div: write filter function/condition that filters between selection box (if condition where points lie within the box)

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; width: 87px; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center;
div.div:
generate javascript function for selection box,
and add in filter condition. Store selection array into data-attr (svg?) to be passed through RDOM.Rcall**?Â

and be able to select over and draw a trendline.

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; width: 325px; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center;
div.div:
** I have no idea if this is going to work (ie can you use RDOM.Rcall within a JavaScript function?)
I haven't managed to implement a selectionbox with DOM yet... so this might be very airy-fairy at the moment.
Once again, the R function would be too specific for this example.
Could return a table of values, or go further and plot something.
